audio_caption: The audio begins with the sound of a whoosh. A male speaker introduces the wide-open nature of the US women's 200-meter field, mentioning Allison Felix's focus on the 400 meters and a deep field of contestants vying for Olympic team spots. He plans to look at women who have a chance to make the Olympic team in the women's 200-meter dash, starting with "Sha'Carri Richardson".

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing a female athlete's performance in the 100 and 200-meter dashes, noting her strong times and potential for winning. He says, "She has been dominating the 100-meter dash", and states that her 200-meter time is "the fastest time by an American woman this year." The speaker transitions to predicting her success at trials, suggesting she will contend for a double win.

The audio clip begins with speech from a male speaker who introduces Gabby Thomas as a newcomer to the event but still familiar with the territory, and summarizes her previous race results and recent performance. The speaker sounds informative and somewhat analytical. Then, music begins, but there is no information available on the genre, mood, or instruments.

The audio clip features a male speaker discussing a recent track and field race, highlighting the winner's performance at the USATF Golden Games, mentioning her time and the slightly wind-aided conditions. He further notes the quality of the competition and anticipates a future match-up, sounding enthusiastic. He then introduces another athlete, Jenna Prandini.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing Prandini's accomplishments and current form, highlighting her potential to make the Olympic team. He transitions to discussing Alison Felix, acknowledging her as one of the greatest sprinters and her past Olympic achievements. He acknowledges Felix's near miss in the 2016 Olympics, commenting on her recent performances and suggesting she's in good form. The speaker notes Felix's intention to compete in both the 400 and 200-meter events, remarking on how she will fare in the 200-meter following the 400-meter event.

The clip starts with one male speaker introducing Brittany Brown, the silver medalist in the 200m at the 2019 Doha World Championships, saying "we have to take a look at" her. He notes that despite winning silver, she has been "a bit under the radar" relative to the other athletes and proceeds to summarize her recent performance, including her windy times and her focus on strength training, mentioning her attempts in a 400m race and personal best time. He concludes that "making the team will be the first step" for her goal to back up her Doha medal.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker providing information about an athlete. He describes her performance at a competition in Doha, mentions her personal best time, and compares it to another athlete's performance. He then notes that she is still in the NCAA, highlighting her potential impact at upcoming championships and the Olympic trials, using a casual and informative tone.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing track and field, mentioning "Desiree Bryant" and her performance at the "2019 World Championships." He notes her personal best time and her finish in the Doha final, concluding that she "cannot be counted out." The tone is informative and analytical.

The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing a track and field athlete named Morolake Akinosun, highlighting her prominence in the 100-meter dash but emphasizing her strong performance in the 200-meter as well. He mentions her recent time of 22.53 seconds and its ranking in the United States, and he concludes by suggesting listeners keep an eye on her potential. The speaker uses an excited and informative tone.

The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing female athletes, mentioning "Kyra Jefferson, 2017 NCAA champion" and "Tiana Daniels, 2019 USA champion." He speaks in a moderately paced, informative tone, describing their personal bests and potential for Olympic competition.

The audio clip features a male speaker enthusiastically discussing female athletes in college athletics, specifically highlighting their track and field achievements, like running a personal best time. The speaker mentions names and affiliations, for example, "Tamara Clark of Alabama." He suggests some athletes might be able to make the 200-meter team. The tone is informative and enthusiastic, emphasizing performance and potential.

The audio begins with a male speaker discussing Kennedy Flannell, a runner from Texas. He mentions her personal best time and her performance at the NCAA championships, highlighting that the women's 200 meters is not as clear-cut going into the US Olympic trials. The speaker's tone is informative and enthusiastic.

The audio begins with a single male speaker enthusiastically stating his predictions for a sports team, expressing confidence in certain athletes due to their speed, consistency, and experience. He mentions a few specific names and then contemplates another athlete's chances. Following this, a quick chime sound is briefly heard.

The audio clip starts with a person listing their picks to make "the women's 200-meter team" and acknowledging that they "very well could be completely wrong" by the time the "US Olympic trials comes around." The speaker then encourages listeners to share their own predictions in the comments, like and subscribe, and come back again. The audio ends with a whooshing sound effect.
